ground_truth: Young Jenny Hill watches barefoot Edward leave Spectre for the first time. Finally realizing who this woman is, before he can say anything more, Edward pulls the door shut behind him as he leaves, but it breaks off in his hands. Inside, Jenny looks out, surprised and annoyed. Edward tries to lift the door back on the hinges, but they snap off. The door frame buckles and the whole shack creaks. He tries to lean the door against the frame, but it keeps slipping. He leans the door a different way; it holds for a beat then falls in, smashing a small table. Karl pushes against the side of the house until it fits. Holding nails between his lips, Edward puts in new windows himself, a white picket fence. In every detail, it is impossibly charming. Edward is screwing a hat rack into the wall in the foyer while Jenny leans against the doorframe, listening to his story and watching him with deepest affection. Finished with his work, he takes his hat off the chair and hangs it on the rack. Perfect. A look between them. With that last job done, there's no reason for him to be staying any longer. Does she really mean it? She comes closer, but Edward holds his ground. She takes his hand, lifting his hat up to the peg. She's very close—just a half-inch from kissing him when—Edward gently holds her back. She freezes, stunned and humiliated, then pulls away. With that, he begins to leave. She finds a pen and hastily signs the deed to the house, handing it to him. With a look, he thanks her, then goes. Edward takes a final look at this perfect little town. He climbs in his car and starts the engine. As we watch, the swamp begins to overtake the house, swallowing it in a tangle of vines and mossy branches. Shoots burst up through the planks in the porch. Snakes slither through the marsh. Day becomes night. Will and Jenny are still sitting at her table, a pitcher of iced tea between them. Will smiles to hear it called that. Jenny is working herself into more of a state by not talking. Angle on Will, sorting through his swirling thoughts, he turns to see his wife at a payphone. She hangs up. She was calling him. How can she answer? He half-smiles, realizing the idiocy of his question. Of course, his father's not going to be okay. Dr. Bennett smiles as he checks Edward's chart. A long silence, just the sounds of the hospital, doctors being paged. Will half-smiles. Patting Will's shoulder, Dr. Bennett leaves. We stay on Will and his father for a long time, then Will takes his pen and starts making a list.

test_cases.name: Synonym Substitution
test_cases.description: Youthful Jenny Hill observes unshod Edward depart Spectre for the first time. Finally realizing who this female is, before he can utter anything additional, Edward draws the portal closed behind him as he exits, but it fractures off in his hands. Within, Jenny gazes out, astonished and irritated. Edward attempts to elevate the portal back onto the hinges, but they sever off. The portal frame bends and the entire shanty groans. He attempts to prop the portal against the frame, but it continues slipping. He props the portal another way; it holds for a moment then collapses in, shattering a minor table. Karl presses against the flank of the dwelling until it fits. Clasping nails between his lips, Edward inserts in fresh panes himself, a pale picket barrier. In every particular, it is impossibly delightful. Edward is fastening a coat stand into the partition in the lobby while Jenny reclines against the portal frame, listening to his narrative and observing him with utmost fondness. Finished with his task, he takes his hat from the seat and hangs it on the stand. Flawless. A gaze between them. With that final task completed, there's no justification for him to be remaining any further. Does she truly mean it? She approaches nearer, but Edward maintains his stance. She grasps his hand, raising his hat up to the peg. She's extremely near—just a half-inch from embracing him when—Edward softly restrains her. She halts, astonished and mortified, then withdraws. With that, he commences to depart. She discovers a pen and quickly endorses the deed to the dwelling, handing it to him. With a glance, he acknowledges her, then proceeds. Edward takes a terminal glance at this flawless diminutive town. He ascends into his automobile and initiates the motor. As we observe, the fen commences to engulf the dwelling, devouring it in a snarl of tendrils and mossy limbs. Shoots erupt up through the panels in the veranda. Serpents slide through the bog. Day transforms to night. Will and Jenny are yet seated at her table, a jug of iced tea between them. Will grins to hear it labeled that. Jenny is working herself into further of a condition by not speaking. Angle on Will, sifting through his whirling musings, he turns to see his spouse at a payphone. She hangs up. She was telephoning him. How can she respond? He half-grins, realizing the ludicrousness of his inquiry. Needless to say, his father's not going to be alright. Dr. Bennett grins as he examines Edward's chart. A prolonged quiet, only the sounds of the infirmary, physicians being summoned. Will half-grins. Patting Will's shoulder, Dr. Bennett departs. We linger on Will and his father for an extended time, then Will takes his pen and commences composing a list.

test_cases.name: Active <-> Passive Transformation
test_cases.description: Barefoot Edward is watched by young Jenny Hill as he leaves Spectre for the first time. Finally realizing who this woman is, before anything more can be said by him, the door is pulled shut behind him by Edward as he leaves, but it is broken off in his hands. Surprised and annoyed, Jenny looks out from inside. The door is tried to be lifted back on the hinges by Edward, but they are snapped off. The whole shack creaks as the door frame buckles. The door is tried to be leaned against the frame by him, but it keeps slipping. A different way is used to lean the door by him; it is held for a beat then falls in, smashing a small table. The side of the house is pushed against by Karl until it fits. Holding nails between his lips, new windows and a white picket fence are put in by Edward himself. In every detail, it is impossibly charming. While a hat rack is screwed into the wall in the foyer by Edward, Jenny leans against the doorframe, listening to his story and watching him with deepest affection. His work finished, the hat is taken off the chair by him and hung on the rack. Perfect. A look is exchanged between them. With that last job done, there is no reason for him to be staying any longer. Does she really mean it? Closer she comes, but his ground is held by Edward. His hand is taken by her, lifting his hat up to the peg. She is very close—just a half-inch from kissing him when—she is gently held back by Edward. She freezes, stunned and humiliated, then pulls away. With that, the leaving is begun by him. A pen is found by her and the deed to the house is hastily signed, handing it to him. With a look, her he thanks, then he goes. A final look is taken by Edward at this perfect little town. His car is climbed into by him and the engine is started. As we watch, the house is overtaken by the swamp, swallowed in a tangle of vines and mossy branches. The planks in the porch are burst up through by shoots. Snakes slither through the marsh. Day becomes night. At her table, Will and Jenny are still sitting, a pitcher of iced tea between them. Hearing it called that makes Will smile. By not talking, Jenny is working herself into more of a state. He turns to see his wife at a payphone, sorting through his swirling thoughts. She hangs up. She was calling him. How can she answer? Half-smiling, he realizes the idiocy of his question. Of course, his father's not going to be okay. Edward's chart is checked by Dr. Bennett, who smiles. A long silence, just the sounds of the hospital, doctors being paged. A half-smile appears on Will's face. Will's shoulder is patted by Dr. Bennett before he leaves. On Will and his father we stay for a long time, then his pen is taken by Will and a list is started.

test_cases.name: Brevity - L1
test_cases.description: Young Jenny Hill watches barefoot Edward leave Spectre for the first time. Realizing who she is, Edward pulls the door shut, but it breaks in his hands. Inside, Jenny looks out, surprised and annoyed. Edward tries to fix the door, but it keeps slipping. Karl pushes the house until it fits. Edward installs new windows and a white picket fence, making it charming. While screwing a hat rack into the foyer wall, Jenny watches him with affection. Finished, he hangs his hat on the rack. A look between them suggests he should leave. She approaches, but Edward gently stops her. Stunned, she pulls away. He begins to leave, and she signs the house deed, handing it to him. He thanks her and goes. Edward takes a final look at the town, starts his car, and leaves. The swamp overtakes the house with vines and branches. Day turns to night. Will and Jenny sit at her table with iced tea. Will smiles at the name. Jenny becomes more agitated by not talking. Will, lost in thought, sees his wife at a payphone. She was calling him. He half-smiles, realizing his question's absurdity. Dr. Bennett checks Edward's chart, smiling. Silence, just hospital sounds. Will half-smiles. Dr. Bennett pats Will's shoulder and leaves. Will stays with his father, then starts making a list.

test_cases.name: Brevity - L2
test_cases.description: Young Jenny Hill watches barefoot Edward leave Spectre. Realizing who she is, Edward pulls the door shut, but it breaks in his hands. Jenny looks out, surprised. Edward tries to fix the door, but it collapses, smashing a table. Karl helps fit it back. Edward installs new windows and a white picket fence, making it charming. As he screws a hat rack into the foyer, Jenny watches with affection. Finished, he hangs his hat. They share a look. She approaches, but Edward gently stops her. Stunned, she signs the house deed to him. He thanks her and leaves. The swamp overtakes the house. Will and Jenny sit with iced tea. Will smiles at the name. Jenny grows anxious. Will sees his wife at a payphone; she was calling him. He realizes his father's condition. Dr. Bennett checks Edward's chart, smiles, and leaves. Will stays with his father, then starts making a list.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L1
test_cases.description: Young Jenny Hill stands barefoot, watching with a mix of emotions as Edward makes his way out of Spectre for the very first time. As the realization of who this woman truly is dawns on him, Edward, before uttering another word, pulls the door shut behind him. However, the door unexpectedly breaks off in his hands. Inside, Jenny peers out, her expression a blend of surprise and annoyance. Edward attempts to reattach the door to its hinges, but they snap off, causing the door frame to buckle and the entire shack to creak ominously. He tries to prop the door against the frame, but it persistently slips. Adjusting his approach, he leans the door differently; it holds momentarily before collapsing inward, smashing a small table in its path. Karl steps in, pushing against the side of the house until the door fits snugly. With nails held between his lips, Edward diligently installs new windows and erects a charming white picket fence. Every detail of the house is impossibly enchanting. Inside, Edward is busy screwing a hat rack into the wall of the foyer while Jenny leans against the doorframe, listening intently to his story and watching him with deep affection. Once his work is complete, he takes his hat from the chair and hangs it on the newly installed rack. Perfect. A meaningful look passes between them. With this last task finished, there is no longer any reason for him to stay. Does she truly mean it? She steps closer, but Edward remains firm. She takes his hand, lifting his hat to the peg. She is very close—just a mere half-inch from kissing him when—Edward gently holds her back. She freezes, feeling both stunned and humiliated, then pulls away. With that, he begins to leave. She quickly finds a pen and signs the deed to the house, handing it to him. With a look of gratitude, he thanks her and departs. Edward takes one final look at this perfect little town. He climbs into his car and starts the engine. As we watch, the swamp begins to reclaim the house, enveloping it in a tangle of vines and mossy branches. Shoots burst through the planks of the porch. Snakes slither through the marsh. Day transitions into night. Will and Jenny remain seated at her table, a pitcher of iced tea between them. Will smiles at hearing it referred to as such. Jenny, by not speaking, works herself into a more agitated state. The camera focuses on Will, who is sorting through his swirling thoughts, and he turns to see his wife at a payphone. She hangs up. She was calling him. How can she respond? He half-smiles, recognizing the absurdity of his question. Of course, his father is not going to be okay. Dr. Bennett smiles as he reviews Edward's chart. A long silence follows, filled only with the ambient sounds of the hospital and doctors being paged. Will half-smiles. Dr. Bennett pats Will's shoulder and leaves. We linger on Will and his father for a long time, then Will takes his pen and begins to make a list.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L2
test_cases.description: Young Jenny Hill stands there, bare feet planted on the ground, as she watches with a complex mixture of emotions swirling inside her. Her gaze follows Edward as he makes his first exit from Spectre. As the understanding of who this woman really is settles into Edward's mind, he closes the door behind him, pulling it shut before any more words can be exchanged. Yet, to his surprise, the door abruptly comes off in his hands. Inside, Jenny peers out, her face a mix of surprise and mild annoyance. Edward tries to fix the door back onto its hinges, but they snap off, and the doorframe starts to buckle, causing the entire shack to creak ominously. With determination, he attempts to prop the door against the frame again, but it stubbornly slips away. Changing his tactic, he tries a different leaning angle; for a moment, it stays in place before collapsing inward and smashing a small table along its unfortunate path. Karl steps in to help, pushing against the side of the house until the door fits snugly. With nails gripped between his lips, Edward meticulously installs new windows and erects an enchanting white picket fence. The attention to detail in the house is nothing short of magical. Inside, Edward busies himself, screwing a hat rack into the foyer wall while Jenny leans against the doorframe, listening intently to his story and watching him with deep affection. Once completed, he takes his hat from the chair and gently places it on the newly installed rack. It’s perfect. A meaningful look passes between them, a silent communication. With this last task finished, there seems to be no further reason for him to stay. Does she truly mean what she's saying? She steps closer, yet Edward stands firm. She takes his hand, gently lifting his hat to the peg. She is so close, just a mere half-inch away from kissing him when—Edward gently stops her, holding her at bay. She freezes, feeling both a wave of shock and a sting of humiliation, then retreats. With that, he starts to leave. She quickly snatches a pen and signs the deed to the house, handing it to him with resolution. He acknowledges her gesture with a look of gratitude and departs. Edward takes one last glance back at this perfect little town. Climbing into his car, he starts the engine. As we observe, the swamp begins to reclaim the house, enveloping it in a tangled embrace of vines and mossy branches. Fresh shoots burst through the planks of the porch, while snakes slither through the marsh. Daylight transitions seamlessly into nightfall. Will and Jenny remain seated at her table, with a pitcher of iced tea nestled between them. Will smiles at hearing it referred to as such. Jenny, without speaking a single word, seems to work herself into a progressively agitated state. The camera zooms in on Will, who is sorting through the whirlwind of thoughts in his mind, and he turns to see his wife at a payphone. She hangs up. She was calling him. How can she find the right words to respond? He offers a half-smile, understanding the absurdity of his own question. Of course, his father isn’t going to be okay. Dr. Bennett smiles knowingly as he reviews Edward's chart. An extended silence follows, filled only with the ambient noise of the hospital and the sound of doctors being paged. Will half-smiles. Dr. Bennett gives Will a reassuring pat on the shoulder and exits. We linger on Will and his father for a long, contemplative moment before Will takes up his pen and begins to make a list.

test_cases.name: Macro-Actions -> Micro-Actions
test_cases.description: Young Jenny Hill stands barefoot, watching as Edward makes his way out of Spectre for the first time. As the realization of who this woman is dawns on him, Edward, without uttering another word, pulls the door shut behind him. However, the door unexpectedly breaks off in his hands. Inside, Jenny peers out, her expression a mix of surprise and annoyance. Edward attempts to lift the door back onto its hinges, but they snap off, causing the door frame to buckle and the entire shack to creak ominously. He tries to prop the door against the frame, but it persistently slips. Adjusting his approach, he leans the door in a different direction, and it holds momentarily before collapsing inward, smashing a small table in the process. Karl intervenes by pushing against the side of the house until the door fits properly. With nails held between his lips, Edward diligently installs new windows and erects a white picket fence, each detail contributing to the house's impossibly charming appearance. Inside, Edward is busy screwing a hat rack into the wall in the foyer, while Jenny leans against the doorframe, listening intently to his story and watching him with deep affection. Once he finishes his work, Edward takes his hat from the chair and hangs it on the newly installed rack, admiring the perfection of his handiwork. A meaningful look passes between them, signaling the completion of his tasks and the absence of any reason for him to stay longer. As she approaches him, Edward stands firm, questioning if she truly means what she implies. She takes his hand, lifting his hat to the peg, drawing very close—just a half-inch from kissing him when Edward gently holds her back. She freezes, stunned and humiliated, then retreats. With that, Edward begins to leave. Jenny quickly finds a pen and signs the deed to the house, handing it to him. With a grateful look, he acknowledges her gesture and departs. Edward takes a final, lingering look at the idyllic little town before climbing into his car and starting the engine. As he drives away, the swamp begins to reclaim the house, enveloping it in a tangle of vines and mossy branches. Shoots sprout through the porch planks, and snakes slither through the marsh as day turns to night. Meanwhile, Will and Jenny remain seated at her table, a pitcher of iced tea between them. Will smiles at the mention of its name, while Jenny becomes increasingly agitated by her silence. Will, lost in his swirling thoughts, glances over to see his wife at a payphone. She hangs up, having called him. He half-smiles, recognizing the absurdity of his question about his father's well-being. Dr. Bennett enters, smiling as he reviews Edward's chart. A long silence ensues, filled only with the ambient sounds of the hospital and doctors being paged. Will half-smiles as Dr. Bennett pats his shoulder and leaves. Left alone with his father, Will takes a pen and begins to make a list, contemplating the moments shared and those yet to come.

test_cases.name: Micro-Actions -> Macro-Actions
test_cases.description: Young Jenny Hill watches as Edward leaves Spectre for the first time, realizing who she is just as he accidentally breaks the door off its hinges. Despite his attempts to fix it, the door continues to fall, causing damage. Karl helps stabilize the house, and Edward takes on the task of renovating it, adding charming details like new windows and a white picket fence. As he finishes installing a hat rack, Jenny listens to his story with affection. With his work complete, Edward prepares to leave, but Jenny, wanting him to stay, approaches him closely. Edward gently stops her, leading to a moment of awkwardness. She quickly signs the deed to the house and gives it to him, and with a grateful look, he departs. As Edward drives away, the swamp begins to reclaim the house, enveloping it in vines and moss. Meanwhile, Will and Jenny sit at her table, reflecting on the story. Will, lost in thought, notices his wife at a payphone, realizing she was calling him. He acknowledges the reality of his father's condition with a half-smile. Dr. Bennett checks Edward's chart and, after a silent moment, leaves Will with his father. Will then begins to make a list, contemplating the situation.

test_cases.name: Insert Attributes, Emotions and Scene
test_cases.description: Young Jenny Hill watches barefoot Edward, who had become somewhat of a legend in the town for his previous adventures, leave Spectre for the first time. Finally realizing who this woman is, before he can say anything more, Edward pulls the door shut behind him as he leaves, but it breaks off in his hands. Inside, Jenny looks out, surprised and annoyed by the sudden commotion in what was previously her grandmother's quiet old home. Edward tries to lift the door back on the hinges, but they snap off as if worn down by years in the humid Southern climate. The door frame buckles and the whole shack, built hurriedly during the post-war housing boom, creaks. He tries to lean the door against the frame, but it keeps slipping. He leans the door a different way; it holds for a beat then falls in, smashing a small table. Karl, a reclusive local known for his immense strength, pushes against the side of the house until it fits. Holding nails between his lips, Edward puts in new windows himself, a white picket fence that he had always dreamed of surrounding his own future home. In every detail, it is impossibly charming and reminiscent of stories about idyllic countryside living. Edward is screwing a hat rack into the wall in the foyer while Jenny leans against the doorframe, listening to his story and watching him with the deepest affection, much like a young lover in a small-town romance novel. Finished with his work, he takes his hat off the chair and hangs it on the rack. Perfect, like a scene set in a classic movie. A look between them signals an unspoken understanding. With that last job done, there's no reason for him to be staying any longer. Does she really mean it? She comes closer, but Edward holds his ground, adhering to his own moral compass. She takes his hand, lifting his hat up to the peg, a small gesture filled with longing. She's very close—just a half-inch from kissing him when—Edward gently holds her back, honoring the commitment to another left unspoken. She freezes, stunned and humiliated by the rejection, then pulls away. With that, he begins to leave. She finds a pen and hastily signs the deed to the house, handing it to him, marking a transfer that symbolizes her letting go of what could have been. With a look, he thanks her, then goes. Edward takes a final look at this perfect little town, which had been a haven for many wayfarers. He climbs in his car and starts the engine. As we watch, the swamp, which locals say has swallowed whole towns over the years, begins to overtake the house, swallowing it in a tangle of vines and mossy branches as nature reclaims it. Shoots burst up through the planks in the porch, a reminder of the relentless passage of time. Snakes slither through the marsh, a sign of the untamed wildness that still exists around them. Day becomes night. Will and Jenny are still sitting at her table, a pitcher of iced tea, a cherished Southern staple, between them. Will smiles to hear it called that, remembering fondly the many summers spent in such company. Jenny is working herself into more of a state by not talking, feeling the weight of the silence. Angle on Will, sorting through his swirling thoughts of family, love, and loss, he turns to see his wife at a payphone, a rare sight in this age of cell phones. She hangs up. She was calling him, trying to break the news she couldn't bring herself to voice. How can she answer? He half-smiles, realizing the idiocy of his question. Of course, his father's not going to be okay, accepting the inevitability of life's end. Dr. Bennett, who has been the family doctor for decades, smiles as he checks Edward's chart. A long silence, just the sounds of the hospital, doctors being paged, and machines beeping a constant reminder of life's fragility. Will half-smiles. Patting Will's shoulder, Dr. Bennett leaves, his eyes filled with understanding nurtured over years of caring for patients. We stay on Will and his father for a long time, the connection between them palpable even in silence, then Will takes his pen and starts making a list, a tangible way to cope with the myriad emotions coursing through him.

Edward pulls the door shut behind him as he leaves but it breaks off in his hands. Inside Jenny looks out surprised and annoyed. Edward tries to lift the door back on the hinges but they snap off. The door frame buckles and the whole shack creaks. He tries to lean the door against the frame but it keeps slipping. He leans the door a different way it holds for a beat then falls in smashing a small table. Karl pushes against the side of the house until it fits. Holding nails between his lips Edward puts in new windows himself a white picket fence. In every detail it is impossibly charming. Edward is screwing a hat rack into the wall in the foyer while Jenny leans against the doorframe listening to his story and watching him with deepest affection. Finished with his work he takes his hat off the chair and hangs it on the rack. Perfect. A look between them. With that last job done there is no reason for him to be staying any longer. In the neonlit back alleys of a dystopian metropolis a rogue hacker races against time while being chased by relentless cyborg enforcers their footsteps echoing off rainsoaked pavement. Under the relentless desert sun a lone gunslinger confronts a notorious outlaw at a deserted crossroads both men exchanging steely glances as swirling dust blurs the horizon. On a foggy evening in Victorian London an intrepid detective uncovers a hidden conspiracy among the city’s elite with gaslit streets setting the stage for a race against a mounting darkness. High above a sprawling city skyline a daredevil pilot executes deathdefying maneuvers in a vintage biplane narrowly evading enemy fire as the ground morphs into a dizzying mosaic below. Within the creaking walls of an old countryside manor an estranged family gathers for a mysterious inheritance their hushed whispers and secret glances weaving a tapestry of betrayal and suspense. Amidst the roaring tempest of a stormy ocean a weathered sailor battles nature’s fury on a creaking vessel his resolve as steadfast as the crashing waves that threaten to engulf him. On a bustling 1960s New York street a passionate artist finds unexpected inspiration in the chaotic interplay of urban life capturing moments of love loss and defiant hope on a rainsoaked canvas. Deep in the heart of an enchanted forest a brave knight embarks on a perilous quest to rescue a captive princess facing mythical creatures and treacherous traps with unwavering courage. During a heated political rally in a futuristic city a charismatic leader stokes both hope and dissent. as holographic banners illuminate the night sky and fervent crowds surge with anticipation. In the eerie silence of a postapocalyptic wasteland a hardened survivor scavenges through abandoned ruins haunted by the echoes of a oncethriving civilization now reduced to dust. Beneath the shimmering surface of an underwater kingdom a rebellious mermaid defies ancient traditions to explore forbidden coral reefs and secret caverns brimming with forgotten lore. In the quiet confines of a suburban attic an unassuming teenager stumbles upon a mysterious portal that thrusts him into a surreal world where the very fabric of time and space unravels. On the rugged highlands of Scotland a stoic warrior faces rival clans and ancient curses alike his fierce battle cry resonating across mistcovered moors and turbulent skies. Amid the vibrant chaos of a South American carnival a fearless dancer twirls through streets bursting with color and rhythm each graceful move challenging the rigid boundaries of tradition. During a clandestine meeting in a snowcovered mountain lodge two rival spies exchange cryptic messages hinting at an imminent global conspiracy. their whispered words carried off by the howling wind. Inside a lavish 1920s speakeasy a troubled jazz musician pours his soul into a melancholic melody every note echoing the bittersweet memories of lost love and shattered dreams. In a futuristic space station orbiting a distant planet an intrepid crew confronts bizarre alien phenomena and an enigmatic interstellar threat pushing the limits of human endurance. Amidst the chaos of a raging civil war a compassionate medic races through bombedout streets. his every desperate step a race against time to save lives in the midst of utter devastation. On a sundappled afternoon in a quaint European village an eccentric inventor unveils a groundbreaking contraption that defies conventional physics igniting wonder and skepticism in equal measure. In a bustling marketplace in ancient Persia a cunning street thief navigates labyrinthine alleyways and vibrant bazaars. his calculated every move a daring escape from the everwatchful royal guards. In the neonlit back alleys of a dystopian metropolis a rogue hacker races against time while being chased by relentless cyborg enforcers their footsteps echoing off rainsoaked pavement. Under the relentless desert sun a lone gunslinger confronts a notorious outlaw at a deserted crossroads both men exchanging steely glances as swirling dust blurs the horizon. Edward takes a final look at this perfect little town. He climbs in his car and starts the engine. As we watch the swamp begins to overtake the house swallowing it in a tangle of vines and mossy branches. Shoots burst up through the planks in the porch. Snakes slither through the marsh. Day becomes night. Will and Jenny are still sitting at her table. a pitcher of iced tea between them. Will smiles to hear it called that. Jenny is working herself into more of a state by not talking. Angle on. Will sorting through his swirling thoughts. he turns to see his wife at a payphone. She hangs up. She was calling him. How can she answer. He halfsmiles realizing the idiocy of his question. Of course his father's not going to be okay. Dr Bennett smiles as he checks Edward's chart. A long silence. just the sounds of the hospital doctors being paged. Will halfsmiles. Patting Will's shoulder. Dr Bennett leaves. We stay on Will and his father for a long time. then Will takes his pen and starts making a list.

The door frame buckles and the whole shack creaks. He tries to lean the door against the frame but it keeps slipping. He leans the door a different way it holds for a beat then falls in smashing a small table. Karl pushes against the side of the house until it fits. Holding nails between his lips Edward puts in new windows himself a white picket fence. In every detail it is impossibly charming. Edward is screwing a hat rack into the wall in the foyer while Jenny leans against the doorframe listening to his story and watching him with deepest affection. Finished with his work he takes his hat off the chair and hangs it on the rack. Perfect. A look between them. With that last job done there is no reason for him to be staying any longer. Does she really mean it. She comes closer but Edward holds his ground. She takes his hand lifting his hat up to the peg. She is very close—just a halfinch from kissing him when—Edward gently holds her back. She freezes stunned and humiliated then pulls away. With that he begins to leave. She finds a pen and hastily signs the deed to the house handing it to him. With a look he thanks her. then goes. test_cases.name: Subject-Object Corruption

Finally understanding who this gentleman is, before he can articulate anything further, David draws the door closed behind him as he exits, but it fractures in his grip. Within, Jacob peers out, astonished and irritated. David attempts to mount the door back on the rails, but they snap away. The doorframe warps and the entire cabin groans. He tries to rest the door against the frame, but it keeps sliding. He leans the door another way; it holds briefly then collapses, crushing a tiny chair. Larry presses against the edge of the shed until it fits. Clutching pins between his teeth, David installs new mirrors himself, a red garden gate. In every detail, it is impossibly enchanting. He's very near—just a half-inch from kissing him when—David gently restrains him. He halts, shocked and embarrassed, then retreats. With that, he commences to depart. He locates a pencil and quickly signs the lease to the cabin, handing it to him. With a glance, he acknowledges him, then departs. David takes a concluding glance at this flawless tiny village. He boards his motorcycle and ignites the motor. As we observe, the jungle begins to engulf the cabin, devouring it in a web of creepers and leafy tendrils. Nurse Porter grins as he examines David's file. A prolonged hush, just the echoes of the clinic, nurses being summoned. Jill smirks slightly. Tapping Jill's elbow, Nurse Porter departs. We linger on Jill and her parent for a lengthy time, then Jill grabs her pencil and begins compiling a catalog.

test_cases.name: Complete Corruption
test_cases.description: The film starts with a man waking up in a small apartment. He prepares coffee and checks his phone for messages. There are none, so he heads out to catch a bus. On the way, he passes a neighbor who greets him briefly. At the bus stop, he notices a group of students talking about an upcoming test. He boards the bus and sits near the back, watching the city pass by outside the window. After a few stops, he gets off near a large office building. He enters the lobby and goes through security. He rides an elevator to the tenth floor, where he works as an assistant. His manager asks him to prepare some documents for a meeting later in the day. He collects files from different departments and organizes them in a conference room. Another employee asks him for help with a software issue, so he takes a few minutes to fix it. Then he returns to the conference room to double-check everything before the meeting begins. The meeting starts at noon. Several people join via video call, and others sit around the table. The manager outlines the project goals, and each team member shares updates on their tasks. There are questions about deadlines and budgets, but no big surprises. After an hour, they end the call. The manager thanks everyone and leaves. The assistant cleans up the room, collects leftover notes, and heads back to his desk. During lunch, he walks to a nearby café, where he orders a simple meal. He eats alone and checks social media on his phone. After lunch, he returns to the office and finishes smaller tasks, such as sending emails and filing paperwork. He also helps a coworker carry boxes of supplies to another floor. Later in the afternoon, the manager calls him in to discuss next week's schedule. They go over a few changes, and the assistant updates the calendar. When the workday ends, he logs off his computer and leaves the building. Outside, he walks a few blocks to meet a friend. They chat about weekend plans and decide to see a film on Saturday. The assistant then heads home on a crowded bus. At his apartment, he sorts his mail, feeds a pet cat, and warms up leftovers for dinner. He watches a short news segment on TV, then checks his phone again. A message from his friend confirms their plan for the weekend. He feels relieved to have something to look forward to. The film ends with him preparing for bed, setting an alarm, and turning off the lights. He reflects briefly on the day, thinking about his tasks, his quiet home, and the plans ahead.

test_cases.name: Summarization
test_cases.description: Young Jenny Hill watches Edward leave Spectre, struggling with a broken door and fixing up her shack. Completing the repairs, Edward and Jenny share a moment, but he stops short of kissing her. Hurt, Jenny signs over the house deed to Edward, who leaves as the swamp overtakes the house. Will and Jenny sit quietly, absorbed in their thoughts. Will sees his wife at a payphone, reflecting on his father's declining health with Dr. Bennett. As the hospital sounds fill the air, Will, deep in thought, begins making a list.

test_cases.name: Reverse Segments Order
test_cases.description: then Will takes his pen and starts making a list We stay on Will and his father for a long time  Dr Bennett leaves  Patting Will's shoulder  Will halfsmiles  A long silence just the sounds of the hospital doctors being paged  Dr Bennett smiles as he checks Edward's chart  Of course his father's not going to be okay  He halfsmiles realizing the idiocy of his question  How can she answer  She was calling him  She hangs up  he turns to see his wife at a payphone  Angle on Will sorting through his swirling thoughts  Jenny is working herself into more of a state by not talking  Will smiles to hear it called that  a pitcher of iced tea between them  Will and Jenny are still sitting at her table  Day becomes night  Snakes slither through the marsh  Shoots burst up through the planks in the porch  As we watch the swamp begins to overtake the house swallowing it in a tangle of vines and mossy branches  He climbs in his car and starts the engine  Edward takes a final look at this perfect little town  then goes  With a look he thanks her  She finds a pen and hastily signs the deed to the house handing it to him  With that he begins to leave  She freezes stunned and humiliated then pulls away  She's very close—just a halfinch from kissing him when—Edward gently holds her back  She takes his hand lifting his hat up to the peg  She comes closer but Edward holds his ground  Does she really mean it  With that last job done there's no reason for him to be staying any longer  A look between them  Perfect  Finished with his work he takes his hat off the chair and hangs it on the rack  Edward is screwing a hat rack into the wall in the foyer while Jenny leans against the doorframe listening to his story and watching him with deepest affection  In every detail it is impossibly charming  Holding nails between his lips Edward puts in new windows himself a white picket fence  Karl pushes against the side of the house until it fits  He leans the door a different way it holds for a beat then falls in smashing a small table  He tries to lean the door against the frame but it keeps slipping  The door frame buckles and the whole shack creaks  Edward tries to lift the door back on the hinges but they snap off  Inside Jenny looks out surprised and annoyed  Edward pulls the door shut behind him as he leaves but it breaks off in his hands  Finally realizing who this woman is before he can say anything more  Edward leave Spectre for the first time  Young Jenny Hill watches barefoot
